title: Like Father, Like Son: Kinship-Aware Preference Mapping (KARMA) for Automatic Alignment in Large Language Models
author: Jeesu Jung (Chungnam National University), Chanjun Park (Korea University), Sangkeun Jung (Chungnam National University), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces a framework that could enhance data curation methods for audio-language models, potentially benefiting tasks in audio generation and improvement of alignment for those models.
background: The study investigates how to align responses generated by language models with human preferences more effectively by comparing outputs from models with similar capabilities.
contribution: This paper introduces the Kinship-Aware pReference MApping (KARMA) framework to solve the issue of Response Quality Gap in alignment tuning, achieving more informative preference mapping.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods, such as Reinforcement Learning from AI Feedback (RLAIF), often compared outputs from models with significantly different abilities, leading to trivial distinctions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by systematically pairing responses from models with comparable competencies, enhancing the quality and interpretability of preference data.

key_innovation: KARMA emphasizes kinship among models to generate preference data, ensuring that comparisons are meaningful and relevant to alignment goals.
real_world_impact: Enhancing the alignment process for large language models will improve their utility in real-world applications, enabling them to better meet user preferences and expectations in various contexts.

new_terms.Response Quality Gap: **Response Quality Gap** refers to the discrepancies in the quality of outputs generated by different models, impacting the effectiveness of preference comparisons.
new_terms.Kinship: **Kinship** quantifies the similarity in capabilities among language models, facilitating more informed comparisons during preference mapping.
